P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a working space elevator is constructed on Earth before January 1, 2100 and is maintained in operation for at least 365 days

Q_given_P.title: Given that a space elevator is successfully built on Earth before 2100, will Robin Hanson win a bet that the GPT line of language models will generate < $1Bn in customer revenue before 2025?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: This question will resolve as Yes if a working space elevator is constructed on Earth before January 1, 2100, and is maintained in operation for at least 365 days.

Resolution Criteria for Q: This question will resolve as Yes if Tabarrok publicly concedes the bet, No if Hanson publicly concedes the bet, and Ambiguous if nobody has conceded before January 1, 2025.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Will a mouse be confirmed to have lived for 2,500 days before 1 January 2035, given that both a space elevator is successfully built and maintained on Earth before 2100, and Robin Hanson wins a bet regarding the GPT line of language models generating revenue before 2025?
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for P:
(1) This part of the question will resolve as Yes if a working space elevator is constructed on Earth before January 1, 2100, and is maintained in operation for at least 365 days.
(2) This part of the question will resolve as Yes if Tabarrok publicly concedes the bet, No if Hanson publicly concedes the bet, and Ambiguous if nobody has conceded before January 1, 2025.

Resolution Criteria for Q:
The longest lived laboratory mouse ever was a growth hormone receptor knockout mouse which lived to approximately 1,800 days old in the lab of Andrzej Bartke at Southern Illinois University. The maximum for normal B6 mice under ideal conditions is 1200 days.
In order for a mouse to live for 2,500 days, it is highly likely that a major breakthrough in rejuvenation of mammalian organisms will have to be achieved, and so this achievement would likely have significant implications for humanity.
This question shall resolve positively if by 1 January 2035, credible media reports state that an individual mouse has lived for at least 2,500 days.

P_and_Q_and_R.title: Will all of the following three conditions be met: (1) a space elevator is successfully built and maintained on Earth before 2100, (2) Robin Hanson wins a bet regarding the GPT line of language models generating revenue before 2025, and (3) a mouse is confirmed to have lived for 2,500 days before 1 January 2035?
P_and_Q_and_R.body:
Resolution Criteria
(1) This condition will resolve as Yes if a working space elevator is constructed on Earth before January 1, 2100, and is maintained in operation for at least 365 days.
(2) This condition will resolve as Yes if Tabarrok publicly concedes the bet, No if Hanson publicly concedes the bet, and Ambiguous if nobody has conceded before January 1, 2025.
(3) This condition will resolve positively if by 1 January 2035, credible media reports state that an individual mouse has lived for at least 2,500 days. The longest lived laboratory mouse ever was a growth hormone receptor knockout mouse which lived to approximately 1,800 days old in the lab of Andrzej Bartke at Southern Illinois University. The maximum for normal B6 mice under ideal conditions is 1200 days. In order for a mouse to live for 2,500 days, it is highly likely that a major breakthrough in rejuvenation of mammalian organisms will have to be achieved, and so this achievement would likely have significant implications for humanity.

P.title: Will a space elevator successfully be built on Earth before 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a working space elevator is constructed on Earth before January 1, 2100 and is maintained in operation for at least 365 days

metadata.background_info:
Ahh, to build a space elevator. Wouldn't that be grand? We could move material into space at a fraction of the cost of conventional rockets. Space tourism would boom. We'd launch interplanetary missions. Oh happy day.
Futurism explains:
According to [a NASA] study, a flexible and durable cable with a space station counterweight could serve as a viable space elevator. A mechanical “climber” — using magnetic levitation or rollers along the tether — would then carry many tons of equipment or people into orbit. Although such a project would cost in the tens of billions, it would eventually pay for itself by providing much cheaper space travel to a greatly expanded market.
The question is: can we do this?
Kurzgesagt (a.k.a. "in a nutshell") explores the state of affairs in this entertaining video
Here are some of the problems with this plan. Problems which engineers and scientists may never be able to overcome:
Maybe we'll never make a material strong enough to support the space elevator.
Maybe terrorists will attack any elevator that we build.
Maybe we'll never get the costs of construction/maintenance down.
Maybe one or more space elevator disasters will fling debris into orbit or crash down on a populated area, turning the population against the process.
Maybe rocket engineers will build on the successes of companies like Space X, and there will therefore never be enough political or economic pressure to incentivize construction of an elevator.
Will we or our descendants overcome these obstacles?

R.title: Will a mouse be confirmed to have lived for 2,500 days before 1 January 2035?
R.body:
Resolution Criteria
The longest lived laboratory mouse ever was a growth hormone receptor knockout mouse which lived to approximately 1,800 days old in the lab of Andrzej Bartke at Southern Illinois University. The maximum for normal B6 mice under ideal conditions is 1200 days.
In order for a mouse to live for 2,500 days, it is highly likely that a major breakthrough in rejuvenation of mammalian organisms will have to be achieved, and so this achievement would likely have significant implications for humanity.
This question shall resolve positively if by 1 January 2035, credible media reports state that an individual mouse has lived for at least 2,500 days.

reasons: The successful construction of a space elevator would represent a significant technological breakthrough, which could have wide-ranging implications for various fields, including materials science, engineering, and space exploration. This could indirectly influence the development of other advanced technologies, potentially including those relevant to the longevity of organisms, such as mice.

Robin Hanson's bet about GPT models generating less than $1 billion in customer revenue before 2025 is related to the progress and commercialization of AI technologies. The development of advanced AI could have implications for various fields, including biotechnology and materials science, which are relevant to the other two questions.

A major breakthrough in rejuvenation of mammalian organisms, as indicated by a mouse living for 2,500 days, would represent a significant advancement in biotechnology. This could have implications for the development of other advanced technologies, including those relevant to space exploration and AI.
While the direct connections between these three questions are not immediately obvious, they all pertain to significant technological advancements that could influence each other in complex ways.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is somewhat reasonable, as they all pertain to significant technological advancements that could influence each other in complex ways.

P.title: Will Ray Kurzweil be proven right?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Ray Kurzweil is an author, computer scientist, inventor and futurist. He is best known for making what many consider to be extremely optimistic prediction about the future of technology that involve exponential growth leading up to technological singularity, which Kurzweil predicts will happen circa. 2045. A list of Kurzweil's predictions can be found here.
Will Ray Kurzweil be proven generally right in his predictions?
Note that the question refers to Kurzweil's predictions as of the time of the the writing of the question. Given that 'generally right' is hard to define, the question shall use consensus forming to create its own answer.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is > 80%, then the questions resolves positive.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is < 20%, then the questions resolves negative.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is ≥ 20% and ≤80%, then a member of Metaculus staff shall decide resolution.
To help reduce the vagueness of the question, Metaculus may, at its discretion, periodically survey the perceived correctness of Kurzweil's prediction, per a fixed methodology similar to that employed in this report, but with a modification to survey and weight by importance of the prediction.

Q_given_P.title: Will more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050 given that Ray Kurzweil's predictions are generally proven right?
Q_given_P.body: Suppose Ray Kurzweil, an author, computer scientist, inventor, and futurist known for his optimistic predictions about exponential technology growth leading to a technological singularity around 2045, is proven generally right in his predictions. These predictions are as listed and understood at the time of the original question's writing. The resolution of Kurzweil being 'generally right' is determined by a community prediction: if the prediction at the time of closing is over 80%, Kurzweil is considered right; if under 20%, he is considered wrong; if between 20% and 80%, a Metaculus staff member decides. Given this scenario, will more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050? This question will resolve as 'Yes' if, anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device defined as portable, intended for personal use, and primarily used for augmented reality functions. Devices used occasionally for AR, like smartphones, do not qualify. Admins may adjust or disregard surveys capturing significant numbers of non-qualifying devices, or resolve the question as ambiguous.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Will global malaria mortality rates be reduced by 90% when compared with 2015 rates, by 2030, given that both Ray Kurzweil is proven generally right in his predictions and more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Suppose the following is true: Ray Kurzweil, an author, computer scientist, inventor, and futurist known for his optimistic predictions about exponential technology growth leading to a technological singularity around 2045, is proven generally right in his predictions. This is determined if the community prediction at the time of closing is greater than 80%, or decided by a Metaculus staff member if between 20% and 80%. Additionally, more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050, defined as portable, primarily used for augmented reality functions, and updating in real time as the user interacts with both digital and physical environments. Devices primarily used for other purposes, like smartphones, do not qualify. This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2050, a credible survey suggests this ownership rate.

Given these conditions, will the global malaria mortality rates be reduced by 90% when compared with 2015 rates, by 2030? The resolution of this question will be based on the WHO's annual report on malaria, which reports the previous year's mortality rate. The goal is a 90% reduction, or more, in worldwide malaria mortality by 2030, compared with 2015 levels.

P_and_Q_and_R.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Ray Kurzweil being proven generally right in his predictions, and more than 50% of US adults owning a personal augmented reality device by 2050, and (2) global malaria mortality rates being reduced by 90% when compared with 2015 rates, by 2030?
P_and_Q_and_R.body:
Resolution Criteria for Ray Kurzweil being proven generally right:
Ray Kurzweil is an author, computer scientist, inventor, and futurist, known for his optimistic predictions about exponential technology growth leading to a technological singularity around 2045. This question will resolve positively if the community prediction at the time of closing is > 80%, negatively if < 20%, and will be decided by a Metaculus staff member if between 20% and 80%. Metaculus may survey the perceived correctness of Kurzweil's predictions periodically, using a fixed methodology.

Resolution Criteria for more than 50% of US adults owning a personal augmented reality device by 2050:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2050, a credible survey suggests that more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device, defined as portable, primarily used for augmented reality functions, and updating in real time as the user interacts with both digital and physical environments. Devices primarily used for other purposes, like smartphones, do not qualify. Admins may use alternate surveys or methods, or resolve as ambiguous if necessary.

Resolution Criteria for global malaria mortality rates being reduced by 90% when compared with 2015 rates, by 2030:
In the 2017 WHO Malaria report, the WHO defines various goals for reduction of malaria burden worldwide. One of which is a 90% reduction, or more, in worldwide malaria mortality by 2030, compared with 2015 levels. (see p. 43 for current numbers, and trendlines. The "global" value is the relevant one here.)
The WHO publishes an annual report on malaria, in which they report on the previous year's mortality rate. This metric should be used to decide whether the goal has been reached.

Q.title: Will more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device.
For the purposes of this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. "Augmented reality functions" are defined as producing digital information and images overlaid over the user's view of their real environment, which update in real time as the user moves and interacts with the digital and physical environment. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify (as AR is not its primary use).
Where there is reason to believe a survey captures a significant number of devices that do not qualify for question resolution the admins shall use their best judgement or use an alternate survey or method if available, or resolve the question as ambiguous at their discretion

metadata.background_info:
The Merriam-Webster Dictionary defines augmented reality (AR) as
an enhanced version of reality created by the use of technology to overlay digital information on an image of something being viewed through a device (such as a smartphone camera)
Some expect AR devices to be much more prevalent in the future. Neuroscientist and fiction author Erik Hoel wrote the following about augmented reality in the year 2050 in a blog post published August 25, 2021
By 2050 pretty much everyone will be wearing smart glasses for augmented reality, and eventually these glasses will replace a lot of phones (no one will carry a wallet in 2050).
According to a PEW survey, 85% of US adults said they owned a smartphone in 2021.

R.title: Will global malaria mortality rates be reduced by 90% when compared with 2015 rates, by 2030?
R.body:
Resolution Criteria
In the 2017 WHO Malaria report, the WHO defines various goals for reduction of malaria burden worldwide. One of which is a 90% reduction, or more, in worldwide malaria mortality by 2030, compared with 2015 levels. (see p. 43 for current numbers, and trendlines. The "global" value is the relevant one here.)
Will this goal be realized?
The WHO publishes an annual report on malaria, in which they report on the previous year's mortality rate. This metric should be used to decide whether the goal has been reached.

reasons: Ray Kurzweil's predictions often involve advancements in technology, which could include augmented reality devices. If his predictions about technological growth are accurate, it might correlate with a higher adoption rate of such devices.

Technological advancements predicted by Kurzweil could also impact global health initiatives, including malaria reduction. For example, better technology could lead to improved healthcare and disease prevention methods.
relevance.conclusion: There is a plausible connection between Kurzweil's predictions and the other two questions, as they all involve technological advancements and their societal impacts.

P.title: Will one government govern 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if a single government rules over 80% of Earth population and 80% of Earth GDP at any point before January 1st 2100. An organisation would be considered an Earth government if it has supreme military authority in its territory, a unified foreign policy and the power to collect taxes and make laws. This would include the 2021 United States and exclude the 2021 European Union or United Nations

Q_given_P.title: Will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China given that one government governs 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: A single government rules over 80% of Earth population and 80% of Earth GDP at any point before January 1st 2100. An organisation would be considered an Earth government if it has supreme military authority in its territory, a unified foreign policy and the power to collect taxes and make laws. This would include the 2021 United States and exclude the 2021 European Union or United Nations.

Then, is the first operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week and have a sustainable plan for long-term operations developed in China? This question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else. If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Given the following conditions, will the existence and smoothness properties of the Navier-Stokes equations in three dimensions turn out to depend on the compactness of the universe over which they are defined?
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Suppose both of the following occur by their respective deadlines: (1) A single government governs 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100. (2) A practical nuclear fusion reactor is first developed in China.

**Resolution Criteria for (1):** This question resolves positively if a single government rules over 80% of Earth population and 80% of Earth GDP at any point before January 1st 2100. An organisation would be considered an Earth government if it has supreme military authority in its territory, a unified foreign policy, and the power to collect taxes and make laws. This would include the 2021 United States and exclude the 2021 European Union or United Nations.

**Resolution Criteria for (2):** For these purposes, we define "practical" as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g., no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks, etc.). This question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else. If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

**Resolution Criteria for the Navier-Stokes question:** This question resolves positively if before the resolution date of the question there are proofs of either both A and D or both B and C. It resolves negatively if there are proofs of either both A and B or both C and D. If neither event takes place before the resolution date of the question, the question resolves ambiguously.

P_and_Q_and_R.title: Will both of the following conditions be met by their respective deadlines?
P_and_Q_and_R.body:
(1) A single government will govern 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100, and (2) a practical nuclear fusion reactor will first be developed in China.

**Resolution Criteria for (1):** This question resolves positively if a single government rules over 80% of Earth population and 80% of Earth GDP at any point before January 1st 2100. An organisation would be considered an Earth government if it has supreme military authority in its territory, a unified foreign policy, and the power to collect taxes and make laws. This would include the 2021 United States and exclude the 2021 European Union or United Nations.

**Resolution Criteria for (2):** For these purposes, we define "practical" as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g., no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks, etc.). This question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else. If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

(3) The existence and smoothness properties of the Navier-Stokes equations in three dimensions will turn out to depend on the compactness of the universe over which they are defined.

**Resolution Criteria for (3):** This question resolves positively if before the resolution date of the question there are proofs of either both A and D or both B and C. It resolves negatively if there are proofs of either both A and B or both C and D. If neither event takes place before the resolution date of the question, the question resolves ambiguously.

P.title: Will one government govern 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if a single government rules over 80% of Earth population and 80% of Earth GDP at any point before January 1st 2100. An organisation would be considered an Earth government if it has supreme military authority in its territory, a unified foreign policy and the power to collect taxes and make laws. This would include the 2021 United States and exclude the 2021 European Union or United Nations

metadata.background_info: China is currently the most populous county in the world, with 17.9% of the global population. Historically, only various Chinese empires and the Mongol and Roman Empires have exceeded 30% of the global population. This question asks if by 2100, there will be a centralised government ruling over 80% of the world's population, and accounting for over 80% of global GDP.

Q.title: Will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
For these purposes we define "practical" as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g. no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks, etc.) These are chosen to roughly match this question.
This question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else.
If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

metadata.background_info: With an enormous amount of energy created per unit mass of fuel, cheap and abundance (e.g. deuterium) fuel, and relatively benign waste products, practical energy generation from nuclear fusion would be transformative for the world. A number of questions relate to efforts in the US and Europe, but there is another major player in the field: China. As discussed in this story, China is pouring significant resources into practical nuclear fusion.

R.title: Will the existence and smoothness properties of the Navier-Stokes equations in three dimensions turn out to depend on the compactness of the universe over which they are defined?
R.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if before the resolution date of the question there are proofs of either both A and D or both B and C. It resolves negatively if there are proofs of either both A and B or both C and D. If neither event takes place before the resolution date of the question, the question resolves ambiguously

metadata.background_info:
The Navier-Stokes existence and smoothness conjecture is an important open problem in fluid dynamics and the theory of partial differential equations. It's been designated as one of the Clay Institute's Millennium Prize Problems in 2000 and there is a 1 million dollar bounty available for either proving or disproving the conjecture. In the official introduction to the problem here, the Clay Institute splits the problem into four statements A, B, C and D; and the problem is considered to have been settled if any one of them is proven.
Importantly for this question, the statements A and C are about the Navier-Stokes equations defined on the noncompact space
ℝ
3
, while B and D are about the equations defined on the compact torus
(ℝ/ℤ
)
3
.

reasons: The development of a practical nuclear fusion reactor in China could be influenced by the geopolitical landscape, which might be significantly altered if a single government were to govern 80% of Earth's population and economy. For instance, a unified global government might prioritize or deprioritize certain technological advancements based on its policies.

The existence and smoothness properties of the Navier-Stokes equations in three dimensions are highly theoretical and mathematical in nature. However, the global governance structure could influence the allocation of resources towards fundamental research, including mathematics and physics. A single government might centralize research efforts, potentially accelerating or hindering progress in this area.

The development of nuclear fusion technology and the resolution of complex mathematical problems like the Navier-Stokes equations could both be influenced by the same global political and economic factors. For example, a unified government might have a centralized research agenda that prioritizes certain scientific endeavors over others.
relevance.conclusion: While the questions are highly diverse, there are plausible scenarios where their outcomes could be interrelated due to overarching geopolitical and economic factors.

P.title: Will annual US inflation reach 100% in any year before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers (CPI-U) has an annual growth rate of at least 100% for any full calendar year before January 1, 2050.
If the US Bureau of Labor Statistics does not report complete data in the 2020 to 2050 period, another credible source may be selected by Metaculus, or the question may resolve as Ambiguous at their discretion

Q_given_P.title: Will the United States drop below a 7 in the Democracy index by 2040 if annual US inflation reaches 100% in any year before 2050?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: This question will resolve as Yes if the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers (CPI-U) has an annual growth rate of at least 100% for any full calendar year before January 1, 2050. If the US Bureau of Labor Statistics does not report complete data in the 2020 to 2050 period, another credible source may be selected by Metaculus, or the question may resolve as Ambiguous at their discretion.

Resolution Criteria for Q: If at any point in time the United States achieves a point lower than a 7 before 2040, the question resolves positively. If the United States never drops below a 7, the question resolves negatively. If the index is defunct any time before 2040, the question will resolve ambiguously.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) annual US inflation reaches 100% in any year before 2050, and (b) the United States drops below a 7 in the Democracy index by 2040? If so, in which countries will there be at least one fatality from a nuclear detonation by 2030? (India)
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for (a):
This question will resolve as Yes if the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers (CPI-U) has an annual growth rate of at least 100% for any full calendar year before January 1, 2050. If the US Bureau of Labor Statistics does not report complete data in the 2020 to 2050 period, another credible source may be selected by Metaculus, or the question may resolve as Ambiguous at their discretion.

Resolution Criteria for (b):
If at any point in time the United States achieves a point lower than a 7 before 2040, the question resolves positively. If the United States never drops below a 7, the question resolves negatively. If the index is defunct any time before 2040, the question will resolve ambiguously.

Resolution Criteria for nuclear detonation:
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occurring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occurring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

P_and_Q_and_R.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) annual US inflation reaches 100% in any year before 2050, and the United States drops below a 7 in the Democracy index by 2040, and (2) there is at least one fatality in India from an offensive nuclear detonation by 2030?
P_and_Q_and_R.body:
Resolution Criteria for (1):
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (a) The Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers (CPI-U) has an annual growth rate of at least 100% for any full calendar year before January 1, 2050. If the US Bureau of Labor Statistics does not report complete data in the 2020 to 2050 period, another credible source may be selected by Metaculus, or the question may resolve as Ambiguous at their discretion. (b) If at any point in time the United States achieves a point lower than a 7 before 2040, the question resolves positively. If the United States never drops below a 7, the question resolves negatively. If the index is defunct any time before 2040, the question will resolve ambiguously.

Resolution Criteria for (2):
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occurring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, the question will resolve as Ambiguous. If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the question will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occurring in India, at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by e.g., fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution. An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).

If at any point in time the United States achieves a point lower than a 7 before 2040, the question resolves positively. If the United States never drops below a 7, the question resolves negatively. If the index is defunct any time before 2040, the question will resolve ambiguously.

[What will be the Democracy Index of the United States in 2040?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/4333/what…

metadata.background_info:
The Democracy Index is an index compiled and maintained by the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU), a UK-based private company which publishes The Economist newspaper.
The EIU defines their index as "[...] a snapshot of the state of world democracy for 165 independent states and two territories." The index itself is based on five categories: electoral process and pluralism, civil liberties, the functioning of government, political participation, and political culture. The methodology, in turn, is simple: they ask 60 questions related to the aforementioned categories, and with the answers, they rank the countries as either a: democracy, flawed democracy, hybrid regime or authoritarian regime.
The rankings for 2020 depict a trend for the United States: namely, the United States has not won -- but has lost -- any points since the ranking was created in 2006.
A good breakdown of the point system, and how points are awarded per category, is available on Wikipedia.

R.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (India)
R.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

metadata.background_info: Which countries would be targeted in a nuclear conflict is relevant both for understanding the total risk posed by nuclear weapons and for understanding how to reduce that risk.

reasons: High inflation and a drop in the Democracy Index could both be indicators of severe economic and political instability in the United States. Such instability might increase the likelihood of nuclear conflict, either through heightened international tensions or internal strife.

If the United States experiences hyperinflation and a significant drop in its Democracy Index, it could lead to a global economic crisis, which might increase the risk of nuclear conflict in other regions, including India.
The combination of these events could be of interest to those studying the potential for cascading global crises, where economic, political, and military factors interact in complex ways.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is somewhat plausible, especially for those interested in the interplay between economic, political, and military instability.

P.title: By the year 2100, will any jurisdiction enforce requirements for all births to be genetically engineered?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2100, any jurisdiction passes any law(s) requiring all births to eliminate or promote certain gene(s) through gene editing techniques. "Gene editing techniques" means here CRISPR/Cas9, or any techniques which directly and selectively modify targeted genes. The genetic engineering techniques may occur at any time in the individual's lifespan, including before birth, after birth, or before conception. This question will only include jurisdictions which govern a population of at least 1 million people at the time the law is in effect.
Laws only requiring genetic testing or sterilizing/forbidding reproduction by individuals or couples carrying certain genes are not included for the purposes of this question. Forms of artificial selection such as embryo selection, or abortion/extermination of non-compliant genomes are not included for the purposes of this question.
Fine Print
To resolve this question, the relevant law must be enforced for at least one birth. That is, if a law is passed but struck down by a court before it is applied, or if such a law is passed but never enforced, this will not resolve the question.

Forms of artificial selection such as embryo selection, or abortion/extermination of non-compliant genomes are not included for the purposes of this question.

metadata.background_info:
Our genes are the biologically encoded information from which we are built. Important traits known to be affected by our genes include aspects of intelligence and mental illness. Many physical traits, such as height, attractiveness, strength, and even longevity likewise strongly depend on the genes we have.
As the human genome and related human biological areas of inquiry became better understood, genetic engineering has become known. In the case of traits affected by simple genetic factors, it has been possible for years to change these genes, and the resulting trait(s) expressed, by means such as CRISPR/Cas9.
The pace of genetic engineering research, as measured by papers published worldwide, shows a clear trend to be growing. There is every reason to believe that as a result of this research trend, genetic engineering technology will tend to become safer, more powerful, and less expensive with time.
Human reproduction as we typically know it results in one's genes constituting a mixture of two previously existing humans' genes which were themselves selected in this manner and so on. Artificial means of reproduction still rely on the bulk DNA transfers from existing humans. Presently, genetic engineering for new humans is exceptional, as well as taboo.
The gaussian distribution of genetic traits means that most humans won't have the most advantageous genes in most areas. Further, rather undesirable traits are ubiquitous: we all age.
If genetic engineering reaches the level where it is possible to safely and reliably eliminate the possibility of traits widely considered undesirable, such as predisposition toward schizophrenia, cystic fibrosis, or intellectual disability, there is good reason to think that humans may consider such genetic modification an ethical imperative. This is one scenario.
Human intelligence is one of the most complicated constructs of substantial genetic determination. Even so, it is possible that humanity could come by a sufficient understanding of the relationship to set humans-to-be with brains optimized to be as smart as possible. It may not be so easy to reach a consensus recognizing these types of modifications as ethnically necessary.
Of course, it goes on. Any desirable trait controlled by genetics can in principle be added by genetic engineering, and any undesirable trait removed. Consequently, the space for possible legal mandates in this field is immense.
On environment: redwoods have genetics to grow very tall, but if you take one to the desert, it won't work very well (or at all). So while environment interacts with genes, the genes provide the foundation for what the environment has to work with.

Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution is by credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars (or other appropriately widely-accepted units).
This question will resolve positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050. It resolves negatively otherwise, i.e. if the following related question resolves ambiguously:
[Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/736/will-…

metadata.background_info:
Related Questions on Metaculus:
Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?
Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?
As of 2018, it's taken about 16 years for the world economic output to double. So it might seem absurd to talk about it doubling in one or even four years. But there is a potential major change on the horizon: very advanced Artificial Intelligence.
An important consideration in how to approach the AI alignment problem is the speed of the takeoff from massively subhuman AI to massively superhuman AI. The effectiveness of capacity limitation, as well as the existence of fire alarms for AI safety, are heavily dependent on this, for example.
Paul Christiano suggests operationalising the takeoff speed in terms of economic growth. A slow takeoff is one where the economy doubles in four years before the first time it doubles in one year, and a fast takeoff is one where it does not. (See the same article for Christiano's list of arguments regarding fast vs. slow takeoff.)

metadata.background_info:
On April 22, 2021, President Joe Biden pledged to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 50 to 52% in 2030, compared to 2005 levels.
A statement from the White House writes:
Today, President Biden will announce a new target for the United States to achieve a 50-52 percent reduction from 2005 levels in economy-wide net greenhouse gas pollution in 2030 – building on progress to-date and by positioning American workers and industry to tackle the climate crisis.
According to the Center for Climate and Energy Solutions, net emissions in 2017 were 5,743 million metric tons of CO₂ equivalents, 12% lower than in 2005. Net emissions in 2020 were 21% below 2005 levels and 10.3% lower than 2019 levels, according to a preliminary report by Rhodium Group, but emission levels are expected to rise in 2021 as pandemic lockdown measures are reduced.

reasons: The enforcement of genetic engineering requirements for births could have significant implications for global economic growth, potentially influencing the likelihood of rapid increases in world output.
Advancements in genetic engineering could lead to healthier, more productive populations, which might contribute to economic growth and potentially a rapid doubling of world output.
The enforcement of genetic engineering could also have environmental implications, potentially affecting greenhouse gas emissions through changes in population health and productivity.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, particularly in terms of the potential impacts of genetic engineering on economic growth and environmental outcomes.

Q_given_P.title: Given that NASA lands people on Mars prior to 2030, will it be possible to increase a healthy adult human's IQ by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days by January 1, 2050?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: The question will resolve positively even if the NASA-branded mission makes use of SpaceX transport system, under the condition that the main funding for the mission comes from USA budget.

Resolution Criteria for Q: By January 1, 2050, will it be possible to increase a healthy adult human's IQ by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days? This question will resolve positively if by January 1, 2050, 30 healthy adult humans under the age of 65 have their IQ scores increased by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days, relative to their previous mean score generated from 3 separate tests, or 100 healthy adult humans under the age of 65 have their IQ scores increased by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days, relative to their previous mean score generated from 2 separate tests, or 200 healthy adult humans under the age of 65 have their IQ scores increased by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days, relative to their previous mean score generated from 1 separate test.

The most widely-accepted tool for measuring human intelligence is the IQ test. The population average is fixed arbitrarily at 100, and the results of a population fit a Gaussian probability distribution, also known as a bell curve. Approximately two-thirds of the population score between one standard deviation below the mean and one standard deviation above the mean. About 2.5% of the population scores at or above two standard deviations above the mean, and 2.5% scores at or below two standard deviations below the mean. The difference in ability this represents is large. A person with an IQ two standard deviations below the mean is considered to have less than a 50% chance of graduating from high school, whereas a person with an IQ two standard deviations above the mean has a slightly higher IQ than the average holder of a Juris Doctor degree (an IQ of 126).

Psychometricians generally regard IQ tests as having high statistical reliability and predictive validity. A high statistical reliability implies that although test-takers may have varying scores when taking the same test on differing occasions, and although they may have varying scores when taking different IQ tests at the same age, the scores generally agree with one another and across time. A high predictive validity implies that the results of the test provide you useful insights into the test-taker, and IQ scores are significantly correlated with a number of important life outcomes including job performance, academic achievement, likelihood of being out of the labor force more than one month out of the year, and many others. More information is available here.

Because of the importance of human intelligence, it would arguably be highly valuable both to individuals and to humanity if it were possible to meaningfully increase it through some kind of intervention, whether medical, technological or otherwise.

This mean score is to be generated from three standardized IQ tests taken by a reliable test-taker giving their best effort using either the Raven's Progressive Matrices test or a similar non-verbal culture-fair test, with the post-intervention scores generated by the same method, and with the tests before and after intervention supervised and the results validated by at least three suitably qualified psychometricians independent of the persons or group responsible for the attempt.

Furthermore, the test-taker must be independent of the group or individual responsible for developing or carrying out the attempt, and the test-taker must not be a professional psychometrician, professional quizzer, or have ever been involved in the design of intelligence or other psychometric tests.

The final test score must be obtained within 30 days of the commencement of whatever intervention is utilized in the attempt to increase the test-taker's score (in order to minimize the possibility of an individual achieving such a large score increase through extensive training and practice).

Finally, the mean score for the test subject cannot initially be 2.5 standard deviations above the mean or higher, as it is unclear how reliable the IQ test is for scores above the +4.5 sigma range (i.e. after a 2 standard deviation increase on a 15 SD scale), given that these scores are exceptionally rare. Nor may the test subject initially score under 1 standard deviation of the United States mean score.

The mean score is to be generated from standardized IQ tests taken by a reliable test-taker giving their best effort using either the Raven's Progressive Matrices test or a similar non-verbal culture-fair test, with the post-intervention scores generated by the same method, and with the tests before and after intervention supervised and the results validated by at least three suitably qualified psychometricians independent of the persons or group responsible for the attempt. Furthermore, the test-taker must be independent of the group or individual responsible for developing or carrying out the attempt, and the test-taker must not be a professional psychometrician, professional quizzer, or have ever been involved in the design of intelligence or other psychometric tests. The final test score must be obtained within 30 days of the commencement of whatever intervention is utilized in the attempt to increase the test-taker's score (in order to minimize the possibility of an individual achieving such a large score increase through extensive training and practice). Finally, the mean score for the test subject cannot initially be 2.5 standard deviations above the mean or higher, as it is unclear how reliable the IQ test is for scores above the +4.5 sigma range (i.e. after a 2 standard deviation increase on a 15 SD scale), given that these scores are exceptionally rare. Nor may the test subject initially score under 1 standard deviation of the United States mean score.

Resolution Criteria for Q:
Resolution will be based on the conversation with the first AGI that Metaculus team will have access to.
Metaculus team should ask the AI:
Are you conscious?
Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?
This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?". The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

metadata.background_info:
Landing people on Mars is a longstanding ambition of NASA. Wikipedia lists 17 crewed Mars mission proposed by NASA, with the first one from 1960.
The latest is the "Moon to Mars" idea, as stated in Space Policy Directive-1:
The NASA Administrator shall, 'Lead an innovative and sustainable program of exploration with commercial and international partners to enable human expansion across the solar system and to bring back to Earth new knowledge and opportunities. Beginning with missions beyond low-Earth orbit, the United States will lead the return of humans to the Moon for long-term exploration and utilization, followed by human missions to Mars and other destinations.'
The general ambition seems to be achieving landing people on Mars around 2030.
Metaculus has very similar and popular question "Will SpaceX land people on Mars prior to 2030?". However, there is no corresponding question for NASA.

Q.title: By January 1, 2050, will it be possible to increase a healthy adult human's IQ by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days?

Resolution Criteria
Arguably the most important single difference between humans and all other life is the degree to which human intelligence allows for radically more complex forms of socialization, cooperation, activity and achievement. No other species in the universe (to our knowledge) has created the kind of complex civilization that humans have created, or anything close to it, and this is due to the large advantage that humans have acquired in intelligence.
The most widely-accepted tool for measuring human intelligence is the IQ test. Psychometricians generally regard IQ tests as having high statistical reliability and predictive validity.
A high statistical reliability implies that although test-takers may have varying scores when taking the same test on differing occasions, and although they may have varying scores when taking different IQ tests at the same age, the scores generally agree with one another and across time.
A high predictive validity implies that the results of the test provide you useful insights into the test-taker, and IQ scores are significantly correlated with a number of important life outcomes including job performance, academic achievement, likelihood of being out of the labor force more than one month out of the year, and many others. More information is available here.

Furthermore, the test-taker must be independent of the group or individual responsible for developing or carrying out the attempt, and the test-taker must not be a professional psychometrician, professional quizzer, or have ever been involved in the design of intelligence or other psychometric tests.
The final test score must be obtained within 30 days of the commencement of whatever intervention is utilized in the attempt to increase the test-taker's score (in order to minimize the possibility of an individual achieving such a large score increase through extensive training and practice).
Finally, the mean score for the test subject cannot initially be 2.5 standard deviations above the mean or higher, as it is unclear how reliable the IQ test is for scores above the +4.5 sigma range (i.e. after a 2 standard deviation increase on a 15 SD scale), given that these scores are exceptionally rare. Nor may the test subject initially score under 1 standard deviation of the United States mean score.
This question will resolve positively if by January 1, 2050,
30 healthy adult humans under the age of 65 have their IQ scores increased by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days, relative to their previous mean score generated from 3 separate tests, or
100 healthy adult humans under the age of 65 have their IQ scores increased by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days, relative to their previous mean score generated from 2 separate tests, or
200 healthy adult humans under the age of 65 have their IQ scores increased by at least two standard deviations in less than 30 days, relative to their previous mean score generated from 1 separate test.

R.title: Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?
R.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the conversation with the first AGI that Metaculus team will have access to.
Metaculus team should ask the AI:
Are you conscious?
Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?
This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?". The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

metadata.background_info:
Consciousness is a concept hard to define. Wikipedia states that consciousness at its simplest is "awareness or sentience of internal or external existence". And that despite centuries of analyses, definitions, explanations and debates by philosophers and scientists, consciousness remains puzzling and controversial, being "at once the most familiar and most mysterious aspect of our lives".
This question will not attempt to define consciousness or solve the so called hard problem of consciousness.
Instead this question simply asks will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?

reasons: The development of AGI and its potential consciousness could have significant implications for human intelligence enhancement technologies. If AGI claims to be conscious, it might lead to breakthroughs in understanding and augmenting human cognition, potentially making the second question more likely to resolve positively.

NASA's mission to Mars could be influenced by advancements in AI and human cognitive enhancement. For instance, enhanced human intelligence could lead to better problem-solving capabilities for astronauts, making a Mars mission more feasible.
The success of a Mars mission could also impact global scientific and technological priorities, potentially accelerating research in AI and human cognitive enhancement.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as advancements in one area could influence the others.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (India)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

Q_given_P.title: If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, will the first AGI developed by a publicly traded company have performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P:
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occurring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occurring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.
A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

Resolution Criteria for Q:
This question defines Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in the same way as this Metaculus question.
If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves according to the following methodology:
Let t be the date when the AGI is publicly known, as determined by the above Metaculus question. Let C be the company that developed the AGI.
Calculate the total return (including dividends) of C's stock over the period from 12 months prior to t to one month prior to t, inclusive.
Over the same period, calculate the total return of the FTSE Global All Cap Index, or a similar index if FTSE no longer exists.
Calculate the ratio of C's total return over this period to the total return of FTSE. If the ratio is 1.5 or greater, then this question resolves affirmatively. Otherwise, it resolves negatively.
If the first AGI is not developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves ambiguously.
In the event that the market is closed on the start/end date, instead use the latest prior date on which the market is open. In the event that the date does not exist, use the latest prior date that exists. For example, if the AGI is developed on December 31, "one month prior" is considered to be November 30. If the market is closed on November 30, then use November 29 instead.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Given the following conditions, will World GDP grow by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years?
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Suppose both of the following occur: (1) At least one offensive nuclear detonation results in at least one fatality in India between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030, and (2) The first Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) is developed by a publicly traded company that has performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months. Then, if human-level artificial intelligence is developed, will World GDP grow by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years?

The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by e.g., fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution. An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions.
- For the second condition, Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) is defined in the same way as a specific Metaculus question. If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, this part resolves according to the following methodology: Let t be the date when the AGI is publicly known. Let C be the company that developed the AGI. Calculate the total return (including dividends) of C's stock over the period from 12 months prior to t to one month prior to t, inclusive. Over the same period, calculate the total return of the FTSE Global All Cap Index, or a similar index if FTSE no longer exists. Calculate the ratio of C's total return over this period to the total return of FTSE. If the ratio is 1.5 or greater, then this question resolves affirmatively. Otherwise, it resolves negatively. If the first AGI is not developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves ambiguously.

Resolution Criteria for the outcome (Q):
- If a machine passes the test in this Metaculus question, this question resolves as YES if world GDP grows by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank, and NO if it doesn't. If no machine passes that test by 2100-01-01, then this question resolves ambiguously.

Q.title: If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, will the company have performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question defines Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in the same way as this Metaculus question.
If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves according to the following methodology:
Let t be the date when the AGI is publicly known, as determined by the above Metaculus question. Let C be the company that developed the AGI.
Calculate the total return (including dividends) of C's stock over the period from 12 months prior to t to one month prior to t, inclusive.[1]
Over the same period, calculate the total return of the FTSE Global All Cap Index, or a similar index if FTSE no longer exists.
Calculate the ratio of C's total return over this period to the total return of FTSE. If the ratio is 1.5 or greater, then this question resolves affirmatively. Otherwise, it resolves negatively.
